abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the project was
            satisfactory. The borrower, Comision Federal de Electricidad
            (CFE) was highly effective, with a strong commitment from
            the executing agency, which exceeded in some instances, the
            targets of the project. However, a disappointing result was
            the demand coincidence factor, overestimated by the
            consultant, and not detected during supervision. It is
            important to mention that Mexico was selected as a pilot for
            testing verification of carbon savings, and a technical
            audit will validate project results in terms of greenhouse
            gas emissions. The key lessons learned suggest that: 1) the
            establishment of independent trust funds was a key factor
            for successful sales and coverage goals, showing to be
            efficient, expeditious and inexpensive; 2) the choice for
            fluorescent bulbs (FLs) with high technical specifications
            and reliability favored consumer acceptance. Furthermore,
            from an overall marketing/ sales point of view, the price
            subsidy was an asset. 3) an adequate tariff policy should be
            in place, providing in turn, incentives to low income
            consumers; and, 4) decentralization of Implementing Units
            was paramount in achieving sales and distribution goals.
